0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Merck has decided to stop production of ATTENUVAX(R) (Measles Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine.
  • Measles; Prophylaxis: 0.5 mL SC

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Merck has decided to stop production of ATTENUVAX(R) (Measles Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine.
  • safety and effectiveness have not been established in infants below the age of 6 months
  • Measles; Prophylaxis: 0.5 mL SC at 12 to 15 months of age, followed by revaccination with MMR II at 4 to 6 years of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Merck has decided to stop production of ATTENUVAX(R) (Measles Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine [1].
  • Measles; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Blood dyscrasias, leukemia, lymphomas, malignant neoplasms of bone or lymphatics
  • Congenital or hereditary immunodeficiency, family history of (immune competence of potential vaccine recipient must be determined)
  • Febrile illness, severe
  • History of anaphylaxis to neomycin
  • Hypersensitivity to any component of the vaccine, including gelatin
  • Immunodeficiency states, primary and acquired (cellular immune deficiencies, hypogammaglobulinemia, dysgammaglobulinemia)
  • Immunosuppressive therapy (does not apply to corticosteroid replacement therapy)
  • Malignant neoplasms of the bone marrow or lymphatic system
  • Pregnancy
  • Pregnancy should be avoided for 28 days postvaccination based on Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommendations; pregnancy should be avoided for 3 months postvaccination based on manufacturer recommendations

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Active, untreated tuberculosis
  • Defer vaccination for at least 3 months following blood or plasma transfusions, or administration of immune globulin
  • Fever may occur following vaccination
  • History of cerebral injury, individual or family history of convulsions, or any condition in which stress due to fever should be avoided
  • HIV-infected patients
  • Hypersensitivity to eggs
  • Special care should be taken to ensure that the injection does not enter a blood vessel
  • Temporary depression of tuberculin skin test sensitivity
  • Thrombocytopenia (may exacerbate condition)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea
  • Neurologic:Dizziness, Headache
  • Other:Fever
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Ataxia, Encephalitis (rare), Encephalopathy (rare), Febrile seizure, Guillain-Barr syndrome, Seizure, Seizure, Afebrile

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Measles virus vaccine live is a highly immunogenic vaccine derived from Enders' attenuated Edmonston strain. It promotes immunity against measles (rubeola) virus by inducing measles hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) antibodies. Seroconversion in response to measles vaccination is clinically proven to confer protection from this disease.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for SUBQ use only; do not administer IV or IM
  • Subcutaneous
    • do not give concurrently with immune globulin
    • give in outer aspect of upper arm
    • reconstitute with supplied diluent and shake well
    • should be given one month before or after administration of other live viral vaccines

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Recommend female patients of childbearing age use reliable contraception to avoid pregnancy up to 3 months post-vaccination.
  • This vaccination should be deferred at least 3 months following blood or plasma transfusions and administration of immune globulin.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, headache, fever, ataxia, or seizures (with or without fever). Drug may also cause or exacerbate thrombocytopenia.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering).
  • Advise patient to avoid receiving vaccines from one month before to one month after this vaccination, unless approved by healthcare professional.
